foliation.note: Numbering in brown ink at the centres of the the upper margins of the rectos. Several stubs bearing fragments of text follow f. 1:136. Images of the versos of these stubs have been numbered [1:137-1:141] for the purposes of this digital catalogue record.

In this catalogue record, this sequence is followed for Part 1 only (i.e. up to 1:136 and the subsequent stubs). However, in the manuscript, the sequence continues beyond that point, throughout Part 2 and ending abruptly in Part 3, as follows: 1:149-1:216, 1:217α, 1:217β, 1:217γ, 1:217δ, 1:217ε (for Part 2, ff. 2:1-73) | 1:230-1:231 (for Part 3: ff. 2:74-75).
Numbering in brown ink or pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

In this catalogue record, this foliation sequence is followed for Parts 2, 3, and 4. It was originally added only to Part 2 in the 17th-century and was later cropped and crossed out in many places. However, a modern hand has subsequently restored the sequence and continued it into Parts 3 and 4.
Numbering in brown ink at the centes of the upper margins of the rectos. This foliation has been crossed out and is not followed here.
Numbering in brown ink at the right upper corners rectos. This foliation has not been crossed out and is not followed here.
Numbering in brown ink at the right upper corners rectos. This foliation has not been crossed out and is not followed here.
Numbering in brown ink at the right upper corners rectos. This foliation has been crossed out and is not followed here.

collation.p: The collation has not been established for any of the four parts.

physDesc.additions: A 17th- or 18th-century hand has written the title: Liber Medicamentorum on f. [i] recto.

binding.p: 17th- or 18th-century brown speckled leather over pasteboards. The spine with five raised bands, gold-tooled filets, a red leather label with the gold-stamped inscription: LIBER MEDICAMENTORUM with, below, the gold-stamped inscription MS.

provenance.p: Thomas Whalley (c. 1584-1637) Whalley, Thomas, c. 1584-1637, Vice-Master of Trinity College, cleric, priest, and bibliophile: his ownership inscription in the lower margin of f. 2:157v: Th. Wh[a]lley possidet.

acquisition.p: Probably bequeathed to Cambridge, Trinity College, by Thomas Whalley Whalley, Thomas, c. 1584-1637 in 1637. The College's current classmark (R.14.39) is inscribed in pencil on the front pastedown, in brown ink on f. [i] recto, and on f. 15r. The alpha-numerical elements are printed separately onto three paper labels pasted onto the spine (not photographed). The manuscript's former classmark R.8.16 is inscribed in brown ink on f. [i] verso (crossed out). Its ex libris, featuring an engraving of its heraldic arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas), and name (Coll: Trin: Cant:) by William Stephens, fl. c. 1740-c. 1760 (W. Stephens sculp.) pasted onto f. [i] recto. Its library stamps on ff. 1:15r, 1:136v, 2:1r, 2:16r, 2:73v, 2:74r, 2:105a recto, 2:106r, and 2:160v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue
Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge
Uroscopy in Middle English: A Guide to the Texts and Manuscripts

series.title: Studies in medieval and renaissance history

monogr.title: Middle English Medical Recipes and Literary Play, 1375-1500

msItem.title: Definitions of Dies caniculares, Dies Materiales, and Dies Artificiales
msItem.incipit: 1:23r Dies caniculares sunst dies in quibus apparet quedam stella meridionalis
msItem.explicit: 1:23r Dies quidam dicunt materiales: quidam artificiales . naturales dies sunt a prima bona usque ad .24. Artificales uero ab ortu solis usque ad occasum

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains recipes in Middle French on f. 27r.

msItem.title: Extracts on chirurgy attributed to Brunus Longburgensis (Cyrurgia magna) and Abū Zayd Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq al-'Ibādī [Joannitius]
msItem.author: Brunus Longburgensis
Abū Zayd Ḥunayn ibn Isḥāq al-'Ibādī [Joannitius]
msItem.incipit: 1:28r Cirugia quid sit est manualis operatio in corpore animalis ad sanitatem tenden
msItem.explicit: 1:28v Triplex est aut humoralis aut aquosa aut ventosa, humoralis alia [...] alia Collerica alia flammatica aut

msItem.title: Poem on the twelve signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 1:29v Aries vnum signum ex corpore humano scilicet caput et faciem / Taurus collum et gutur frigida et sicca
msItem.explicit: 1:29v Scorpio verenda testiculos vexicam anum et inferioram / Sagittarius femora et ancas vsque ad Jenua
msItem.note: The poem is accompanied by a table showing the twelve months and their constellations.

msItem.title: Astrological poem
msItem.incipit: 1:30r Pectus pulmo Iecur in cancro non minuetor
msItem.explicit: 1:30v Piscis habet lunam poli curare podagra / Et si capis iter tunc ad locum tardius ibis / Embrio conceptus epilenticus exit avuluo

msItem.title: Note on chirurgy
msItem.incipit: 1:30v Notandum quod omniumque debet fieri incisio cum ferro
msItem.explicit: 1:30v et Ipocras dum vulnera que Indropicis finit non sanantur

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.incipit: 1:31r Tabula medicinarum profieicentium renibus et lapidibus

msItem.title: Medical recipes for treating kidney stones
msItem.rubric: 1:31v De medicinis proficientibus renibus et lapidibus
msItem.note: The date 1525 is written above one recipe on f. 35v.

msItem.title: Medical recipes for treating eye ailments
Medical treatise and recipes for treating eye ailments
msItem.incipit: 1:42r Apud pale[r]mo nostre artis trades pauca
msItem.explicit: 1:48r [not transcribed]

msItem.title: Treatise on the eye (followed by medical recipes for treating eye ailments)
msItem.rubric: 1:48v Incipiunt quedam alia speculatiua secundum magistrum beneuentum grecum
msItem.incipit: 1:48v quid est oculus est speculum aeris detribus humoribus et ex septem tunicis compositus
msItem.explicit: 1:53r et agita usque ad coagulatienem

msItem.title: Poems on the four humours
msItem.incipit: 1:55r Como il corpo mortal chel senso abraso
msItem.explicit: 1:56v il color suo e , de terra lutulenta

msItem.title: Verses on the four humours
msItem.incipit: 1:56v Colericus audax veloci motus citrinique coleris
msItem.explicit: 1:56v Melanconicus timidus auarus tenax terreijque coloris

msItem.title: Tract on abcesses excerpted from the Canon Medicinae
msItem.author: Avicenna
msItem.rubric: 1:59r Iam locuti sumus in libro primo de apostematibus et speciebus eorum
msItem.incipit: 1:59r Videtur A. male processius cum inmediate post determinationem de febribus determinauit de apostematibus
msItem.explicit: 1:59r tractatum de apo

msItem.title: Extracts on abcesses (apostemata)
msItem.incipit: 1:59r Scilicet dico quod dupliciter contingit loquide solucie continuitatis et de apostematibus vno modo theorice ilio modo via curationis et practice
msItem.explicit: 1:60v [...] esse mortalis

msItem.title: Extracts on fractures
msItem.rubric: 1:61r De fractura cum vulnera ad quam remedium
msItem.incipit: 1:61r Cum invenies aliquid membrum in quo acciderit fractura et vulnerus
msItem.explicit: 1:62v quoniam in eo est timor magnus

msItem.title: Tract on brain injuries
msItem.incipit: 1:62v Lesio autam facta in cerebro est periculosa
msItem.explicit: 1:62v Interdum natura operatus ea que medico inpossibilia videntur

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Several recipes are attributed to the Italian papal physician and surgeon John de Vigo [Giovanni da Vigo]: ff. 1:74r, 1:79r, 1:83v, 1:84r, and 1:102v.

msItem.title: Tract on six types of hernia
msItem.incipit: 1:122r Prima vocatur hernia humoralis
msItem.explicit: 1:122r Sexta et vltima intestinalis et hernia Intestinalis a doctoribus crepatur et nuncupatur

msItem.title: Tract on ruptures
msItem.incipit: 1:122r Crepatura ut antiquis et modernis invenitur scripturis triplex est
msItem.explicit: 1:122v [...] brachijs eleuantibus

msItem.title: Fragmentary leaves
msItem.note: Five stubs bearing fragmentary text. Only the versos of each stub have been photographed.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 1:15-1:136: multiple watermarks, including (but limited to) a bull, crown, hand with a five-pointed start, and a hand with a five-petalled flower.

p.seg: Unruled. Single columns. c. 20-30 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by various hands working in humanistic cursive scripts.

decoNote.p: A small drawing of a furnace with a vessel in dark ink on f. [1:126b] recto.

origin.p: It is possible that this part comprises further smaller codicological units of separate production, including ff. [1:126a]-[1:126b], which has texts written in French on paper with no watermarks and with the (?)16th-century folio numbers 112 and 113 written on them. However, it appears that these parts were joint together soon after their production.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.39, ff. 2:1-2:73

msItem.title: Vita Sanctorum [ending of the life of St Augustine of Canterbury only]
msItem.incipit: 2:1r ye beleve of god and so þai dide preche here þat within a lytell whyle þai hadde conuertede to god kynke herberd and vj Ml of folke with hym and all onon þai werre Cristende of hym
msItem.explicit: 2:1r And tech þe faith of cirst and to redyn and synggyn in holy chirche of gode power and of hys myght and saynt Austyn wrotte ȝeme bookkes to serref god full wyrschypfully thereinne amen

msItem.title: Note about John Goode going to warfare
msItem.incipit: 2:1r Jon goode cannot go warfare but tam [...]keyns schal go wylliam
msItem.note: Added to the lower margin of the page by a late 15th or early 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes in verse and prose
msItem.incipit: 2:1v for sore brystys or pappys - Who so haue sore pappys or bolnyng Make þis playster for any thynge
msItem.explicit: 2:3v And put it in a good grett clovte And þer with wynde þi hed a bowte
msItem.note: This collection includes a prose charm, entitled: ffor þe fallyng evyll a medyson +. It concerns a well-known charm against the Falling Sickness (epilepsy) that instructs a medical practitioner to draw blood from the patient's little finger and use it to write the names of the Three Magi (Jasper, Melchesar, Baltisar) on the patient's forehead. Subsequently, the following versys need to be written on parchment and worn around the patient's neck: Jasper se it Aurum . thus Melchior Attropa mirram hic quicumque trium fert secum nomina regum soluitur a morbo dum pietate caduco

msItem.title: Medical recipe for pain in the head
msItem.incipit: 2:3v Take ij ownsys of betonye and off horhowde as many and vij aincys of pyall ryalle and braye alle to gedir smalle
msItem.explicit: 2:4r And \whan/ it is clensyd clene Rubbe all þi hed be dene All þe hed werke and ake wythyn a whyle from þe shall slake
msItem.note: Not recorded in the Digital Index of Middle English Verse (DIMEV) but evidently belongs to the previous collection of Middle English recipes in prose and verse.

msItem.title: Collection of four medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains recipes for to make a patient make watyr for þe ston, ffor þe kolyke [2 recipes], and An esy medsyn and a good for a woman that travellyth for after throwys. All have been copied by the same hand that copied the previous collection of recipes in Middle English prose and verse.

msItem.title: Collection of sixty two medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection has been copied by a single hand. Among remedies, it features a diagnostic recipe that is entitled ffor to knowe yf a man be smyttyn in þe þe [sic] hede with a stafe yf þe panne be brokyn or natt and þe flesch hole a bovyn and not brokyn (f. 7v). Another recipe provides a remedy for a blow from a staff: A good medsyne for a man þat is blastyd with a spryte to doo awey þe ache and þe swellyng (f. 2:8v).

msItem.title: Collection of six medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for werkyngh off the Sydys, ffor the fote þat is owte of Joynte, ffor hym þat hase lost hyse speche, for werkyngh of þe hede, ffor clensyngh of the hede, for Bolnyng of þe Ere.

msItem.title: Instructions in the perilous and fortunate datys for bloodletting
msItem.rubric: 2:13r To know when is tyme to lat bloode and when is nonne tyme
msItem.incipit: 2:13r Þese er þe dayese of þe ȝere for lattyngh of blode þer er thre dayes in þe ȝere þat \no/ man sal lat hym for no uewyl nor drynke no drynke [sic]
msItem.explicit: 2:13v in þat ȝere nor in no fransye ne tysyke and þese is perliuse from þe xv daye of septembre tyl þe xvij daye of marche

msItem.title: Account of medical treatment for fevers said to have been revealed by an angel
msItem.incipit: 2:13v In capitulo [...] ?admonesterium capitulo porro in verbo ?muneracione dicit hic unicum quod si quarto decimo die mensis febres intrante incipiendo ab inchoacione quis munerit sanguinem illo anno non potest morire cum distemperancia febres et dixit hanc medicinam veram ab angelo divinitus revelatam aliquantulum credo sibi pro eo quod fuit valde antiquus nec mortuus est nisi propter senectutem et non propter distemperanciam febris hec sunt verba Jo. v. ?muneracione et concordat Jo. in. no.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains 17 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains 77 medical recipes.

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains 254 medical recipes; those on ff. 2:27v and 2:28r are written in the margins of the recipe collection on ff. 19r-28r. The collection includes a number of charms (listed separately) and prognostic texts, including ffor to know when a man is smetyn on þe hede with a staffe if þe pan be broeken or noght and þe flesch be bolnede and noght broken (f. 2:42r); To wytte whedyr a man sall lyfe or dyen þat is wondyd (ff. 2:43r-2:43v); To whyte whedyr a man lyfe or dye þat is seike and noght wondede (f. 2:76v); ffor to whytten wheder þe dropsye ben curabyl or non (f. 2:44v-2:45r; To knowe if a woman be wiht chyld (f. 2:55r); The collection includes a few female healthcare recipes, including one that is addressed to midwives: Medicyn to þe þat arn a mydewyffe (f. 2:52v).

msItem.title: Charm for eyesight
msItem.rubric: 2:29r Ad illum qui est extra sensum
msItem.incipit: 2:29r-2:29v ffaciatis signum Thav in fronte infirmi dicendo in nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti amen in nomine ihesu Christi facio signum thav .T. et super thav scribatur istud [u/n][u/n] agla cum aqua benedicta et temperetur cum puluere de cristallo
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm against cramp
msItem.textLang: A Latin charm with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 2:29v A gude medicyn for þe Cramp
msItem.incipit: 2:29v + Sciabal + god + god + god tanay + arax + erax + obuexi [? or: obnexi] + et dicat quinque pater noster et v aue maria quando accipiet probatum est
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm for curing sick animals
msItem.incipit: 2:30r Deus invisibilis et in estimabilis qui pro cuncta diffusus es pietatem et misericordiam tuam per sanctum et tremendum filij tui nomen supplices deprecamur . ut hanc creaturam ordij benedicere + et potenciam invisibilis operacionis ministrandas vt pecora que necessitatis humane tribuere dignatus es
msItem.explicit: 2:30v Quicumque vult et tunc aspergatur aqua benedicta super ordinem dicendo in nomine patris et filij et spiritus sancti Amen
msItem.note: The text specifically refers to pigs, cows, and horses.

msItem.title: Charm for safely delivering a child
msItem.rubric: 2:54r To do a woman deliuerde of a chylde
msItem.incipit: 2:54r-2:54v Take a brode lauere and on the lawere sewe a rowle of parchemente in the qwyche rowll þat þise charme be wretyn in and late the woman gyrde her with that rowll + In nomine patris + et filij + et spiritus sancti + amen Sancta maria vera meter et vera virgo verum infantem genuit et peperit ihesum Christum + Elesabeth + peperit Johannem Baptistat sine dolore + ita et tu N. per ihesum Christum + infanteam pereas + deus + deorum + dominus + locutus est et vocauit terram + Christus vincit + Christus regnat + Christus imperat + Christus familiam suam ob omnium periculo defendat Et tu infans Christus te vocat vt vt nascaris + In nomine patris + et filij + et spiritus sancti + Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription; this charm has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Charm against epilepsy (Falling Evil)
msItem.incipit: 2:56v Say thiese wordes in hyse ryght ere þat hasethe fallyngh ewyll takkyngh hym vp be the ryght hande thriese anamzapta ad hoc me misit vt faueris In nomine ihesu Christi
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Charm for healing wounded animals
msItem.incipit: 2:62v Qwat man or woman þat bryngys the tythyns þat the beste is stonghe make hym to feighe a coppe with drynke the same þat brynges the tytyhynghs and tak þat drynke and sette it on fyve fyngers apoun th ryght honde and say þese wordes owre the drynke blyssyngh + Caro + carose + irrumpitet + Sane + humane + paraclitus + Say thysse resoun iij tymes blyssyngh owr the cowppe and he þat browght the tythynghs latte hym dryngke it of and he sall noght so soun adronken þat the beeste salbe hole foreuer moore
msItem.note: Full transcription; this charm has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Charm to staunch blood
msItem.incipit: 2:64v longeus miles lancea latus saluatoris apperuit et continuo exiuit sanguis et aqua sanguis redempcionis et aqua baptismatis + In nomine patris + Cesset sanguis + restat sanguis + et spiritus sancti + non exeat sanguis amplius de ore vel de vena vel de naso In thise maner sall thys comiuracioun be saide and thre pater noster and also wryten thyese thre names in hyse forhede hospitent + calitente + califient + beronix and if it be a woman + beronixa
msItem.note: Full transcription; this charm has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Charm for treating toothache
msItem.incipit: 2:64v Wryte + il + ill + il + il + ill + with a chalke stoun and than say O Christe pia suplex deprecor Apolinia hinc dolor abscedat nec te manis obsecro ledat In nomine patris et cetera Telo tabernam tabernolo In nomine patris et cetera kyryeleyson Christeleyson Kyryeleyson dicatis ter pater noster et ter Aue et ter Credo
msItem.note: Full transcription; this charm has been crossed out.

msItem.title: Charm to make teeth fall out
msItem.rubric: 2:64v ffor to makke teith to fall owte e thaym self
msItem.incipit: 2:64v-2:65r Takke a watyr frogge and a londe frogge and seth thayme in fair dynnyngh watyr and gedyr tho greise and smere tharewith thy gomes all abowte the soore teithe and saye In nomine Patris et filij et spiritus sancti Amen And makke a crosse and thy tothe sall fall owte
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Accounts
msItem.incipit: 2:68v iiij schoikes and x scharfes summa totalis iijscore and x [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription attempted; partially cropped off.

msItem.title: Treatise on urines [Urine White and Red] (final lines only)
msItem.explicit: 2:69r kyngh woman vryn þat is lykke flexhe þat tokens the woman is to bokkyngh and to haffe thow hem and the menysoun and þat neuer be hole

msItem.title: De Contentis Urinarum
msItem.incipit: 2:69r Gylles telles be autorite of ipocrase þat ofte tyme the colours of vryne desawese the leche and makkys to deme wrongh for he talkes non hedde of the contentys þat ben in the vrynnes and he sayse þat iocrase telles þat men may better wyttyn be the contentis þan be the colours
msItem.explicit: 2:73v brayn tokens grewanse of th bleddyr [...] wytten be the vryn of messallrye [...] le the vryn is hote couerit with a greyn
msItem.note: Portions of the text are missing due to damage to ff. 2:71-2:73.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 2:1-2:72: Various watermarks, predominantly including a pair of , scissors and ?wheels.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Single columns. 24-30 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Copied by various hands working in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

origin.origDate: Second half of the 15th century or first half of the 16th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.39, ff. 2:74-2:105, 2:105a, 2:106-2:112

msItem.title: Treatise on the plague and medical recipes
msItem.incipit: 2:74r In tempore epidimiali id est pestelentiali tale erit regminen
msItem.explicit: 2:75v hoc puluere ipsem more est impossibilie

msItem.title: Prognostications whether the sick will live or die
Prognostications for the days of the week
Prognostications for the months of the year
Tract on the preservation of mental faculties
msItem.rubric: 2:89v De conseruatione memorie et aliarum virtutum sanitatis Cerebri
msItem.incipit: 2:89v Exterior excedens frigiditas sedit memoriam
msItem.explicit: 2:89v memoriam surripit atque aufert

msItem.title: Prognostications for the year based on the weather
msItem.incipit: 2:90r Si pluat in festo, quo virgo purificatur / Ex hoc signatur, quod hyems exinde fugatur / Si sol dat radium, frigus erit nimium Marche drye, maketh goode rye / April weete, maketh good wheete / but maye floode, doth no goode
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: De Judicio Urinarum (I)
msItem.incipit: 2:91r Albus is qhyte as clere water
msItem.explicit: 2:105r Ther be also many oþer vryns betokenyng deth as \it/ is sheweyd to the before in this booke - finis
msItem.note:
This is a compilation of various uroscopic works, including:
Twenty Colors by Digestion Groups on f. 91r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 31 (no. 3.1.1c) where she notes that this copy has been "expanded to twenty-one colors by adding Subviridis after Viridis; no digestion groups named in this late copy, but the colors still follow those groupings].
De Urinis Egrorum features on ff. 91r–98v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 96 (no. 16.5)].
De Urinis Sanorum [The Four Complexions] on f. 91r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 67 (no. 8.3)].
Six-Token List on f. 91v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 38 (no. 4.1.3c)].
Cleansing of Blood on ff. 98v-99r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 35 (no. 3.3.3)].
The Contents on ff. 99r-101r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 69 (no. 8.6)].
Urines of Man, Woman, and Beast on ff. 101r-101v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 56 (no.7.3.4)].
The Doom of Urine hou Shalt Cast in Four on ff. 101r-101v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 58 (no. 7.4)].
Urine White and Brown on ff. 101v, 104v-105r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 44 (no. 5.2.1)].
Urina Rufa on ff. 103r-104v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 33 (no. 3.2)].
Urina Mortis Tam Hominum Quam Mulierum on f. 105r [see Tavormina (2014), p. 28 (no. 2.5b)].
Colours of urine and their Digestions on f. 104v [see Tavormina (2014), p. 50 (no. 6.6)].

msItem.title: List of payments for salaries
msItem.note: The list is accompanied by the notes: Qui pro valdijs suis per diem:, habet per annum: and Qui cap[it] per diem:.

msItem.title: Rules for accounting
msItem.incipit: 2:105v Quadrantes sabato quot nos expendimus vno / Tot crescunt solidi, cum tot nummis numerati
msItem.explicit: 2:105v [last line not transcrbied]

msItem.title: De Judicio Urinarum (II)
msItem.incipit: 2:106r Without knowlege of þe dysease or infiryte it is impossible to helpe any maner of person
msItem.explicit: 2:107v Vrina rubea is as þe fynest saffron subrubeus ys as saffron red [...]

msItem.title: Index of medical recipes in this part of the manuscript
Tract on weight and measures used in medicine
msItem.rubric: 2:110v De ponderibus uel mensuris reperiunter in arte medicinali
msItem.incipit: 2:110v ℈ Scrupulus est trecia pars .3.
msItem.explicit: 2:110v Rafitij est pondus ℈ j etcaetera

msItem.title: Poem on weights and measures
msItem.incipit: 2:110v Collige triticeis medicine pondera granis grana quater quinque scripuli pro pondere pone
msItem.explicit: 2:110v non eris illusus si tenes quod tenit vsus

msItem.title: Medical prognostications based on the day of the month on which the illness begins
msItem.incipit: 2:111r Quisquis prima die cuiuscumque mensis in infirmitatem cecederit
msItem.explicit: 2:111v tricesimo primo die qui egrotauerit vtrum evadet nec ne ignorabit

msItem.title: Medical prognostications based on the astrological sign in which the disease started
msItem.incipit: 2:111v Quinque infirmatus luna existente
msItem.explicit: 2:111v [not transcribed]

msItem.title: Poem on the Four Evangelists
msItem.note: Not transcribed.

msItem.title: Memorandum of John Jennison [Jenyson] of Yaxham, Norfolk
msItem.incipit: 2:112v Memorandum that I delyuered to Edmond greene the day of this memorandum that I John Jenyson of yaxham delyuered John dey of westefeld cxxs of the bequethement of Edmund dey his father in the presens of John Cooke . Harey Note and Robert f[...]k[...] and other at yaxham in the howse of John Dyckson
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Poem
msItem.rubric: 2:112v He that in wealth take no hede / shall fynde defawt in tyme of nede
msItem.incipit: 2:112v Memento this [...]
msItem.explicit: 2:112v his love þat no can doo [...], no man fynde þerto

listBibl.bibl: EV 30774 (Union First Line Index of English Verse)

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 2:74-2:112: various watermarks, predominantly featuring a: hand and unicorn.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, vertical line of frame ruled in ink only (ff. 2:74r-2:105a). Single columns, except for ff. 2:109r-2:110v which have 2 columns. 41-43 lines to the page, written below top line (see f. 2:74r).

handNote.p: This part of the manuscript features several hands writing in humanistic cursive scripts.
This part of the manuscript features several hands writing in cursive scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

additions.p: Dried plant material (a straw) is located in the gutter between ff. 2:114 and 2:115.

provenance.p: Symon Newell (fl. 1526-1541) Newell, Symon, fl. 1526-1541 of Shipdham, Norfolk: owned the manuscript as indicated by a previously unrecorded 16th-century ownership inscription on f. 2:89r: Symon Newell me possidet - Symon Newell de Shypdham in Com. Norffolk. He may be the same Symon Newell/Nevell who in Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.17 is stated to have translated it into English and copied an astrological-medical work that fills the entire manuscript (ff. 1r-119v). The prologue to this unidentified work (f. 1v) reads: [crossed out: Translated and] vryten by me Symon newell in the yere of oure lorde .1535. begon þe 28 daye of marche. A comparison of the scripts in MS O.8.17 and the ownership inscription in MS R.14.39 suggests that they may have been copied by one and the same person. He may also be the very same Symon Newell who is recorded in the for a 'debt of grace' to practice medicine in the early 16th-century accounts of the University of Cambridge (see Grace Book B: Containing the Accounts of the Proctors of the University of Cambridge, 1511-1533, Part 2, ed. by Mary Bateson (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1905), p. 218 and Venn:NVL526 S).

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.14.39, ff. 2:113-2:145, 2:145a, 2:146-2:160

msItem.title: Personal note about a nocturnal pollution after Easter
msItem.incipit: 2:145a recto (upper margin) Wheras I haue offendyd my lorde god on friday at nyght next after Easter in my slepe by polucyon I crye god mercy
msItem.note: Added in the early 16th century. The text was later crossed out.

msItem.title: Treatise on laxatives
msItem.incipit: 2:146r Laxatiuum purgans corpus a colera et alijs humoribus
msItem.explicit: 2:146v [not transcribed]

msItem.title: Recipe for perfuming gloves
msItem.rubric: 2:146v To perfume a payer of gloves

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: The collection contains a recipe, entitled the flower of oyntmentes, that is introduced as a curall for wounds and a method to draw out shards, splinters, and thorns (f. 2:155r).

msItem.title: Table of contents
msItem.note: Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Note about a 1554 publication
msItem.incipit: 2:159v Annotationes scholastice in euangelia dominia et ea quae in festis Jesu Christi, et Sanctorum eius precipuis, leguntur in Ecclesia, per totum annum: collecta et dictata a luca lossio, in schola Luneburgensi Witebergie ex officina Thome Klug Anno .1554.
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

msItem.title: Notes about books brought from York to Richmond
msItem.rubric: 2:160r Anno .1567. 2. Junij - libri quos eboraco mecum Richmando adduxi
msItem.incipit: 2:160r otto brunfelsij 3. librj
msItem.explicit: 2:160r ij librj ex paprio et Numeratus 22 - et mihi acto [...] dati erant
msItem.note: Added by a 16th-century hand.

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 2:113-2:160: various watermarks, predominantly featuring a: hand with five-pointed star, hand with crown, and hand with four-petalled flower.

p.seg: Ruled in ink, vertical outer line of frame only (ff. 2:150r-2:157v). Single columns. 23-35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by various cursive hands scripts with both anglicana and secretary features.

decoNote.p: This part of the manuscript does not contain any significant forms of decoration.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
